Award.AwardTitle: Memristors for Low-Power, Passive RF Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Intellectual Merit: Adaptive impedance matching enables development of low cost hybrid antennas with dynamic beamforming capabilities that will improve the performance of wireless communication. However, there are several challenges with existing approaches including: (i) fixed impedance in hybrid antennas restricts flexibility and prevents dynamic beamforming, (ii) employment of semiconductors for impedance switching has several drawbacks. These include: (a) requirement of ?holding? a transistor in a specific state by maintaining a minimum activation voltage leading to an increase in its energy consumption, and (b) nonlinearity of transistors and semiconductors introduce a bias, which changes the effective impedance between strong and weak signals received by an antenna. In contrast, the goal of this project is to study and design a novel approach to RF front-end design with memristors replacing traditional CMOS-based impedance switching. In particular, the memristor-based RF front ends will be employed in a passive RFID technology and hybrid antenna design. The expected contributions include understanding the performance of memristors in radio frequency (RF) applications, and more flexible design of impedance matching networks for antennas. The end result of this effort could lead to a transformative paradigm in designing antennas and RF front-end devices.
Broader Impact: The main proposal outcomes are a new knowledge and understanding of how different type of memristors could be applied to RF systems such as adaptive antenna arrays for weak signals, and a simplified design of impedance matching networks and their tuning. This will enable new designs of cheaper and simpler beamforming hybrid antennas in passive radio frequency identification (RFID) systems. The benefits will apply to other communication systems such as cognitive networks and radar systems. A set of outreach activities include engagement of women and students from under-represented minorities through the Missouri S&T Student Diversity Programs office and K-12 outreach that engages high school students through the Missouri S&T Summer Research Academy (SRA) program. In the long term, the outcomes will support a number of memristor based technology applications in communication systems including wearable antenna systems and sensors, and enhancing performance and coverage of wireless Internet access systems for rural, currently-not-serviced areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on developing new technologies to improve reliability and communication capability of a passive communication with application to RFID tag. The primary application of the project outcomes is logistics and items tracking where it is economically essential to maintain 99.5% accuracy in inventory, and reducing RFID fixed infrastructure cost through increased communication range of the new RFID tags designed using our technology. Additionally, the advancements in materials development and characterization has application to new, memristive switching-based computer memory development that requires less energy and is faster than current FLASH/SSD memory.

     The main outcomes of the projects include:

  1. Memristive switching technology advancements in terms of new materials with demonstrated capabilities for memory storage.
  2. Complete characterization of the cuprous oxide and cobalt oxide has been obtained and indicate these are promising material with application to radio frequency (RF) communication.
  3. Development of an RF impedance switching circuitry that employs the new materials to enable tuning of RF circuitry with low energy consumption (minimal during tuning and no energy required in stable state).
  4. Professional training and experiential learning and professional skills for over 10 graduate and undergraduate students including 6 female participants. The funding supported two Ph.D. student and senior researcher who already graduated and started successful careers thus enriching US economy.
  5. Increased publicity and dissemination of knowledge in the fields of materials engineering and RFID technology that was supported by NSF. Also, the technical details have been presented at the leading journal and conference including an Best Paper Contender at IEEE RFID 2016 conference
  6. Two patent applications for the technology developed using the NSF support thus supporting the technology transfer.

 

The preliminary research into the oxide based memrisors switching indicates that energy required for writing information to such memory cells requires significantly less energy than previously understood. It would benefit both RF design of communication devices, memristor based memory devices, and logic circuits. This will lead to more energy-efficient electronic devices – potentially replacing existing technology of Flash/NAND memory in SSD and Flash Drives and adaptive processors. Consequently, smaller electronic devices could be developed with significantly lower power requirements.

 

Overall the team gained valuable skills and advanced knowledge and understanding in both material science field of memristive switching and passive, battery-free communication systems, such as RFID tags. The outcomes have potential of providing economic benefits and competitive edge in various industries including logistics, aerospace manufacturing, smart sensor networks for Smart Cities, and healthcare.
